Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Does genetic load drive mating system evolution? Tests in an explicit historical context
Award.AbstractNarration:
This research will quantify the interplay between historical events and current natural selection in shaping plant mating system. Evolution is an ongoing process but depends strongly on the past. While nearly everyone acknowledges this fact, it has been difficult to quantify the relative importance of historical and current selection pressures as explanations of patterns in nature. This research will look at the factors that have determined the amount of self-pollination versus outcrossing in the American bellflower (Campanulastrum americanum). The project will immerse undergraduate and graduate students in the collection of next-generation DNA sequence data to reconstruct historical events and studies of current selective environment in the study species. Analyses of data from these disparate sources into a single, unified framework will provide a clearer understanding of the processes shaping complex patterns in nature, and yields a predictive framework that can be applied in any biological system. Broad dissemination of this predictive approach is valuable because it will help predict the response of species to increasingly altered environments in the modern age.

Plant mating systems are evolutionarily labile, ranging from highly outcrossing to highly inbreeding. This wide variation provides an excellent system for understanding the ultimate drivers of evolutionary change. Variable mating system strategies across levels of the biological hierarchy are commonly explained as adaptations to the current selective environment. A significant fraction of this variation, however, may reflect historical evolution in response to colonization during range expansion. This idea will be tested using Campanulastrum americanum, a North American herb in which preliminary data indicate reduced inbreeding depression and greater autogamy in sites where phylogeographic data suggest recent colonization. Using populations a range of distances from glacial refugia, the researchers will gather data with coalescent analysis of RAD-seq polymorphism, greenhouse studies of fixed and segregating genetic load, field studies of pollen limitation and reproductive assurance, and population-genetic inferences of selfing rates. Analyses of these data will determine whether initially non-adaptive processes associated with range expansion provided a permissive environment for later evolution of the mating system. The research framework therefore provides a mechanism for discerning the ultimate drivers of organismal change across past and present time scales.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Plant mating systems are evolutionarily labile, ranging from highly outcrossing to highly inbreeding. While this profound variation is found among taxa, it is also observed among populations within species. Typically, variation in mating system is explained by hypotheses focusing on the context-dependent benefits of selfing, e.g. guaranteed reproduction when pollinators are scarce. However, an alternative explanation is that historical colonization events during post-glacial range expansion may have shaped mating system. The research supported by this grant undertook a series of studies to address these hypotheses using Campanula americana, tall bellflower, as a model system.

In C. americana there is a striking geographic pattern in mating system. Autonomous fruit set, the ability to reproduce without a pollinator visit, ranges from 34% of flowers in some populations to 76% in other populations. This variation is associated with geography; the further north and further west populations are in its eastern U.S. range, the greater the selfing potential. Detrimental effects of inbreeding are thought to inhibit the evolution of selfing, leading to the prediction of less inbreeding depression in C. americana populations in the north and west. However, we found no association between selfing potential and inbreeding depression. We also found no evidence that ecological factors drove the evolution of selfing potential as it was not associated with population size, pollinator visitation frequency, or selfing rates in nature. However, the influence of genetic drift on populations increased in the north and west of the range and was strongly correlated with selfing potential. Therefore, genetic changes associated with postglacial range expansion likely underlie variation in C. americana's mating system. 

In total, variation in selfing potential among C. americana populations was more closely associated with historical factors, such as post-glacial range expansion, than contemporary ecological factors. This suggests a need to consider historical factors to understand potential response to changing climates.

There were several additional discoveries, unanticipated in the original grant proposal. First, while some floral insect visitors (i.e. pollinators) are true mutualists others remove more pollen than they deposit and therefore serve as pollen predators, suggesting that any changes in the composition of pollinating taxa associated with recent pollinator declines could dramatically affect plant reproduction. Second, pollen color in C. americana varies from white to deep purple with darker pollen more common in western populations apparently due to its greater heat tolerance but less common in the east where it is preferred by inefficient pollinators. Third, mating system in some C. americana populations is plastic, with greater selfing when pollinators are scarce and greater outcrossing when they are common. Flexible mating systems may explain why mixed mating is common, when theory often predicts complete outcrossing or selfing.

Broader Impacts:

1) The research supported by this grant explored how plant responses to historical changes in climate may have affected the mating system. We demonstrated that range expansion after the glaciers receded in C. americana was associated with an increase in selfing potential. This suggests that genetic changes associated with contemporary range shifts may also affect mating system.   

2) This grant supported the development of a successful outreach program between the University of Virginia and Western Albemarle High School's Environmental Studies Academy (ESA). Each year, the PI and UVA graduate students invited ESA students to spend a weekend at UVA's Mountain Lake Biological Station learning about the natural history of the southern Appalachians was well as developing and carrying out student-initiated projects. This program has become a valuable part of ESA's curriculum and will continue beyond the granting period. 

3) This grant supported a number of training opportunities in ecology and evolution and enhanced diversity in the field. Training ranged from working with a faculty member and a number of undergraduate students at College of Wooster, to supporting a Postdoctoral Associate, to providing independent research and lab assistant positions to at least 16 undergraduate students.

4) Research results were disseminated to professional audiences as well as the general public.
